{{Infobox musical artist | name = Andrew Tibbs | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Melvin Andrew Grayson | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1929|2|2|mf=y}} |birth_place =[[Columbus, Ohio]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1991|5|5|1929|2|2|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], urban blues | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Late 1940s–1991 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Andrew Tibbs''' (February 2, 1929 – May 5, 1991) was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues|electric]] and urban blues [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. He is best known for his controversial 1947 recording, "Bilbo Is Dead", a song relating to the demise of [[Theodore G. Bilbo]]. ==Biography== Tibbs was born '''Melvin Andrew Grayson''',{{cite book | first= Adrian | last= Room | year= 2010 | title= Dictionary of Pseudonyms: 13,000 Assumed Names and Their Origins | edition= 5th | publisher= McFarland & Company, Inc. | location= [[Jefferson, North Carolina]] | isbn= 978-0-7864-4373-4 | page= 475}} in [[Columbus, Ohio]], [[United States]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p131854/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Andrew Tibbs |author= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=July 26, 2011}} As a boy he sang in Baptist choirs in [[Chicago]], directed by [[Mahalia Jackson]] and [[Dinah Washington]]. He was influenced by [[Ivory Joe Hunter]] and [[Arnold Moore|Arnold "Gatemouth" Moore]]. From 1947 to 1949, Tibbs originally [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] for [[Aristocrat Records]]. His debut [[Single (music)|single]] was "Bilbo Is Dead" b/w "Union Man Blues", recorded whilst Tibbs was eighteen years old. The tracks were both co-written by Tibbs and [[Tom Archia]], and caused controversy. The [[A-side and B-side|A-side]] criticized Theodore Bilbo's policies, whilst the [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] caused displeasure from the Chicago based [[teamster]] [[trade union]]s. Six further singles were released by Aristocrat. Following its eventual acquisition by [[Leonard Chess|Leonard]] and Phil Chess, the newly formed [[Chess Records|Chess]] [[record label|label]] signed Tibbs in 1950, but he released only one record, "You Can't Win", before being dismissed. Tibbs recorded the "Rock Savoy Rock" single for [[Peacock Records]] in 1951, followed by some unissued sessions for [[Savoy Records|Savoy]]. With his brother, Kenneth, Tibbs recorded one session for [[Atco Records|Atco]] in 1956, which featured [[King Curtis]]. His final recordings in 1962 for M-Pac Records included his last single release, "Stone Hearted Woman".{{cite web |url=http://www.music.us/biography/artist/28423/andrew_tibbs.html |title=Andrew Tibbs : Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Music.us |accessdate=July 26, 2011}} He worked for West Electric thereafter, but made sporadic live appearances in Chicago [[nightclub|clubs]].{{cite web |url=http://www.discovery-records.com/product-ST29979/TIBBS-ANDREW.htm |title=Andrew Tibbs : Classics 1947-1951 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Discovery-records.com |accessdate=July 26, 2011}} Tibbs died in Chicago in May 1991, aged 62.[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1990.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed July 2011 ==Discography== *''1947–1951'' (1991) - Classics Records{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/1947-1951-r595363 |title=1947-1951 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=July 26, 2011}} ==See also== *[[List of electric blues musicians]] *[[List of urban blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME = Tibbs, Andrew | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Grayson, Melvin Andrew | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American urban blues singer | DATE OF BIRTH = February 2, 1929 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Columbus, Ohio]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = May 5, 1991 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tibbs, Andrew}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Ohio]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Urban blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Ohio]]
